content.user_title: Create structured Django plans for autonomous development
content.value_statement: Creating backend features with multiple interdependent tasks is error-prone and hard to track. This skill generates a complete plan directory with quality gates, task files, and prompts that enable autonomous AI execution through the Ralph Wiggum Loop for rigorous, iterative implementation.
actual_capabilities: Generate PLAN.md with task index and dependency tracking
Create RALPH-PROMPT.md with iteration-aware execution instructions
Produce individual task files with checklists and completion criteria
Define quality gates (lint, types, tests, coverage, Django checks)
Track progress with completion status and quality gate results
Configure toolchain commands (ruff, mypy, pytest, django)
limitations: Designed specifically for Django backend projects only
Requires Ralph Wiggum Loop skill for autonomous execution
Does not execute code or run verification commands itself
User must provide task list, paths, and configuration values

prompt_templates.title: Basic plan request
prompt_templates.scenario: Start a new Django backend feature
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a plan for a user preferences API feature in my Django project. The app path is accounts/, module is preferences/, and test filter is 'preferences'. Use ruff for linting and pytest for testing.

prompt_templates.title: Detailed specification
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a plan with these tasks: 1) Add JSON field to User model, 2) Create preferences service, 3) Build API endpoints with Django Ninja, 4) Add Redis caching. Use .bin/ruff check, .bin/ty for type checking, .bin/pytest with --dc=TestLocalApp, 90% coverage target.

prompt_templates.title: Complex dependency mapping
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a plan for a notification service with 6 tasks: models, email service, push service, preferences integration, webhook handlers, and rate limiting. Include execution order that minimizes blocking. Quality gate commands: lint .bin/ruff check, type .bin/ty, test .bin/pytest -k 'notification' --dc=TestLocalApp.

prompt_templates.title: Quality-first approach
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a plan for a data export feature with strict quality gates: 95% coverage target, no TODO comments allowed, require type hints on all functions. Include a warm-up task for codebase orientation before implementing.

output_examples.input: Create a plan for user authentication feature with email verification
output: Quality gates configured: ruff check, ty type check, pytest -k 'auth', 90% coverage

best_practices: Keep each task to 4-8 checklist items for optimal Ralph iteration
Always include a warm-up task for unfamiliar codebases
Define the completion promise with task count to prevent premature exit
Configure all toolchain commands (lint, type, test) before generating the plan
anti_patterns: Creating tasks larger than 8 checklist items causes Ralph to get stuck
Using generic completion promises allows Claude to exit with tasks remaining
Skipping quality gate configuration defeats the purpose of autonomous execution
Not checking task dependencies leads to blocking and wasted iterations

faq.question: What is the Ralph Wiggum Loop?
faq.answer: Ralph is an autonomous execution loop where Claude iteratively works through tasks, reading its previous work from git history to maintain context and progress across iterations.

faq.question: Can this skill be used without Ralph?
faq.answer: Yes, the generated PLAN.md and task files are human-readable and can be used manually. The RALPH-PROMPT.md requires Ralph for autonomous execution.

faq.question: What Django versions are supported?
faq.answer: The skill works with any Django version that supports your tooling. It uses standard commands (django check, pytest) compatible with Django 3.2+.

faq.question: How is data handled during execution?
faq.answer: No data is sent externally. The skill only generates markdown files locally. Verification commands run on your machine with your test data.

faq.question: Why are my tasks not completing?
faq.answer: Common causes: task is too large (split into smaller tasks), quality gates failing (fix the code), or missing dependencies (check task ordering). Review the blockers section in the task file.

faq.question: How does this differ from other planning skills?
faq.answer: This skill specifically generates Ralph-compatible prompts with built-in quality gates and progress tracking for autonomous multi-iteration execution.
